Market pullbacks are a common occurrence, and we can control the risk through stop placement, position sizing and managing cash balances. Any time a stop gets hit, I see it as a chance to upgrade to a better technical opportunity. $SPX $QQQ

$GOOGL trades in a 1.3% daily range (ATR), $TTD in a 4.3% range and $SKLZ in a 7.6% range. Using a fixed 6-7% stop level, without accounting for single stock volatility, is going to lead to alot of whipsaw losses and missed trades.  https://t.co/i2LHbqyWly

$SPX is up 52% of the time on a daily basis & down 48% of the time. LT uptrends are formed by stocks/markets making new highs, then pulling back, followed by more highs and more pullback, etc. Accepting pullbacks helps to offset the 'sell it all' mindset on every red day.

The High-Volatility playbook is still the same:  Very high cash/very low risk exposure Smaller positions Reduced activity, if any Stops on everything Focus on price and risk  Know where the downside risk levels are Know when to switch from offense to defense at any time $SPX
A good reminder with repeated $SPX failed rallies, now below 3000 and the 200-sma.   The right cash allocation is the best buffer to downside, plus reduced activity if any and stops.

In all markets, but esp. higher volatility & $SPX < 200-sma, it is always important to measure & monitor open risk, cash allocations, stops, exits, etc.  It doesn't matter what happened '80% of the time' or in the past. Each market is unique, be sure to keep all risk in check.

I traded through 2000 when many people thought that "great companies" were all you needed, but they determined "great" by stock performance. Some considered "great" names like $LU, $GE, $CSCO, $MSFT, $AOL, $PFE lost 50 - 80% of their value.

A high beta account in 2018 that was -16% & +20% in 2019 is just over breakeven with alot of turnover and "analysis." $SPY was -4.56% in 2018 and +12.89% in 2019 so far, or +7.74%... outpeforming for a few months in the uptrend, but getting blown out in the downtrend is bad math

Newer traders focus on relative returns or "beating the index" - more experienced traders focus on absolute returns (positive returns in all environments). If $SPX is -5% one year and someone is -4%, they "beat the index" but still a bad year.

Holding a basket of 20 high beta, high PE stocks offers very little risk control when markets unwind like they have this month. It's really one or two big high beta positions. An average high beta account underperformed $SPX by 4 to 1 in 2018 (-16% vs - 4%).
